Yotta CEO: AI Infra Bottleneck in India

Massive Buildout  
- $2 Bn+ investment for Asia's largest AI compute hub.  
- Powered by Nvidia Blackwell Ultra GPUs.  
- Current: ~10K advanced GPUs; scaling to 40K soon at Greater Noida.

Market Position  
- Supplies ~75% of India's GPU compute.  
- Serves startups, IITs, IndiaAI Mission govt initiative.

Strategic Focus  
- Sovereign high-performance infra (vs hyperscalers' orchestration/software).  
- Demand not issue‚Äîcompute scarcity is; supply unlocks sectors.

Global View  
- Capital-intensive; only few hubs worldwide (India poised as one).  
- Complementary ecosystem; India stores fraction of its ~20% global data share.

Key Takeaway: GPU ramp signals India AI readiness‚Äîwatch data center capex chain for beneficiaries.

India-Canada Trade Pact Progress

Milestone Ahead  
- To finalise CEPA Terms of Reference (ToR) in early March during Canadian PM Mark Carney's visit.  
- Third attempt after stalls in 2010/2023 due to politics.

Trade Ambition  
- Target: Double bilateral trade to $50 Bn by 2030.  
- 2024 total: $23.66 Bn (merchandise $9.8 Bn, services balance).  
- Apr-Dec 2025 merchandise: $5.8 Bn (India exports $3.38 Bn, imports $2.41 Bn).

Key Flows  
- India exports: Pharma, electronics, gems/jewellery, seafood, engineering goods.  
- Imports: Minerals, pulses, potash, wood pulp, scrap.  
- Canadian FDI in India: $4.2 Bn; portfolio >$75 Bn.

Key Takeaway: CEPA revival unlocks pharma/export upside‚Äîpositive for bilateral trade beneficiaries.

AI Summit ‚ÄòShow-Stealer‚Äô Robot Sparks Made-in-India Controversy

A robotic dog named ‚ÄúOrion‚Äù became a crowd-puller at the India AI Impact Summit, showcased at the stall of Galgotias University.

The quadruped robot was introduced as a creation of the university‚Äôs Centre of Excellence and was widely seen as a Made-in-India innovation.

However, online users quickly identified the robot as the Unitree Go2, a commercially available product made by Unitree Robotics and sold globally for around $2,800.

Social media fact-checking triggered controversy, raising questions about whether a made-in-China product had been presented as an indigenous innovation.

Authorities reportedly asked the university to vacate the stall, while the institution maintained it had not explicitly claimed the robot was made in India.

The episode cast an awkward spotlight on the summit, which aimed to celebrate India‚Äôs indigenous AI capabilities and global ambitions.

Zaggle Prepaid: Common Investor Concerns

Cash & Margins  
- Negative operating cash flow.  
- Upfront reward costs + prepaid float funding strain.  
- High-margin slowdown, low-margin volume growth.  
- ROE & OPM erosion worries.

Business Model  
- Low SaaS revenue share; volume-led expansion.  
- Aggressive acquisitions with goodwill risks.  
- New segments (credit cards) pose execution uncertainty.

Capital & Ownership  
- QIP + high-cost NCD (13.5%) allocation doubts.  
- Retail-heavy ownership base.  

Market Sentiment  
- Liquidity shift: 2024 hype to 2026 realism.  
- Doubts on growth sustainability.  
- Valuation pressure from earnings quality issues.

Key Takeaway: Execution, cash gen, and capital discipline key to rebuilding conviction‚Äîwatch Q4 for inflection.

Afcom Holdings has been officially declared a *Designated Indian Carrier* by the Ministry of Finance. This recognition allows the company to claim an exemption from *29% VAT* on Aviation Turbine Fuel (ATF) used for export operations. Management expects this to reduce overall operating costs by *5% to 7%*, which will directly improve operating margins and financial performance.

Carlton swings from VIP to Safari!

In an interesting development on the Indian bourses, Safari Industries has announced a 20 year licensing agreement with Carlton Retail to exclusively use the ‚ÄúCarlton‚Äù brand in India for luggage and accessories.

This comes after the long running trademark dispute between VIP Industries and Carlton Shoes over ownership of the Carlton name in India. The court had barred VIP from using the brand for its luggage line in the domestic market. Safari is now set to retail backpacks and luggage under the Carlton brand.

For context, Carlton contributed about 4 to 6% of VIP‚Äôs FY25 turnover, translating to roughly ‚Çπ130 cr.

Key agreement details
* Initial term of 20 years with an option to renew for another 20 years at Safari‚Äôs discretion
* License fee of ‚Çπ45 lakh annually or 5% of net sales, whichever is higher
* Interest free refundable security deposit of ‚Çπ100 cr to be paid to Carlton Retail in tranches

Why this could matter for Safari?
1Ô∏è‚É£ Firmer presence in the premium segment through an established global brand. Carlton can complement Safari Select & Urban Jungle & help Safari compete more effectively with players like Samsonite, Mokobara & Delsey.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Safari‚Äôs premium portfolio currently contributes only about 6% of revenue. Scaling Carlton could accelerate premium mix improvement and support margins, given the higher price realisations in this segment.

Execution and brand positioning will be the key monitorables from here.

In 2004, Carlton partnered VIP when Sudhir Jatia was part of the company. In a full circle development, Carlton has now entered into a new agreement with Safari Industries India Ltd. which Jatia currently owns.

üá∫üá∏‚ÄìüáÆüá∑ U.S.‚ÄìIran Tensions Escalate as Military Build-Up Raises Conflict Fears ; Reports

üî• Khazanchi Jewellers ‚Äì Key Future Growth Drivers & Investor Takeaways

üìà Revenue Growth Outlook & Guidance

‚úÖ Industry Outlook
‚Ä¢ Management expects the overall jewellery industry to grow 30‚Äì35%.
‚Ä¢ Company guiding 25‚Äì30% conservative growth across verticals.
‚Ä¢ Management prefers conservative guidance with intent to outperform.

‚úÖ FY27 Growth
‚Ä¢ Targeting 25‚Äì30% YoY growth at business level.
‚Ä¢ Retail expansion expected to accelerate growth further.

üè¨ Retail Expansion ‚Äì The Biggest Structural Trigger

üìå Retail Mix Shift
‚Ä¢ Current mix: 90% B2B | 10% B2C
‚Ä¢ Target: 25% retail contribution in 1‚Äì1.5 years
‚Ä¢ Longer-term ambition: Higher than 25%
üìå Flagship Showroom (Chennai)

‚Ä¢ 10,000 sq. ft. large-format store
‚Ä¢ ‚Çπ20 crore sales in first 10 days
‚Ä¢ Target revenue: ‚Çπ500‚Äì550 crore annually
‚Ä¢ Capex: ‚Çπ12 crore
‚Ä¢ Payback period: ~1.5 years
‚Ä¢ Inventory planned: ‚Çπ150 crore
üìå Store Expansion

‚Ä¢ More company-owned stores planned
‚Ä¢ No fixed number disclosed yet
‚Ä¢ Expansion to be measured, not aggressive immediately
üëâ Retail EBITDA margins: 10‚Äì12% vs 5‚Äì6% in wholesale

‚Üí Retail mix shift is a major margin expansion trigger.
üí∞ Margin Expansion Triggers

Current Position

‚Ä¢ Q3 EBITDA margin: 6%
‚Ä¢ 9M EBITDA margin: 5.78%
Structural Drivers

‚Ä¢ Focus on higher-value designer jewellery
‚Ä¢ Premium natural diamond category (Vajra by Khazanchi)
‚Ä¢ Optimizing volumes in low-margin segments
‚Ä¢ Retail share increase
Guidance

‚Ä¢ EBITDA margin expected to improve 20‚Äì30% from current levels as retail scales
‚Ä¢ PAT margin expected to improve 25‚Äì30% as retail reaches 25%
üíé Diamond Strategy & Premiumization

Natural Diamonds (Not Lab Grown)

‚Ä¢ Expansion under Vajra by Khazanchi
‚Ä¢ Positive response at exhibitions
‚Ä¢ Higher-margin category
‚Ä¢ Targeting profitability uplift through premium positioning
Lab-Grown Diamonds

‚Ä¢ No specific push or strategic commentary on lab-grown.
‚Ä¢ Focus remains on high-quality VVS natural diamonds, especially in South India.
ü™ô Gold Price Commentary & Consumer Trends

On Gold Price Volatility

‚Ä¢ Management does not expect sharp 15% correction.
‚Ä¢ If gold corrects significantly ‚Üí volume surge likely.
‚Ä¢ Current growth is largely value-led.
Q3 Growth Split

‚Ä¢ Revenue up 49.6% YoY
‚Ä¢ Volume growth only 7‚Äì10%
‚Ä¢ Margin expansion driven by mix improvement
Hedging Strategy

‚Ä¢ Natural hedge model (refill what is sold)
‚Ä¢ Exchange hedging for large extra orders
üë• Consumer Behavior & Trends

Key Observations

‚Ä¢ Shift toward lightweight jewellery
‚Ä¢ 20‚Äì25% weight reduction in wedding products
‚Ä¢ Focus on visual size with lower gold content
‚Ä¢ South India still prefers 18K & 22K; little demand for 14K
Organized vs Unorganized

‚Ä¢ Clear shift from unorganized to organized players
‚Ä¢ Consumers prioritizing quality & resale value
Designer Jewellery

‚Ä¢ Making charges vary widely:
‚Ä¢ Chains: 3‚Äì4%
‚Ä¢ Premium Polki/Kundan/Jadau: 22‚Äì23%
‚Ä¢ Design differentiation is key moat
üè¶ Working Capital & Balance Sheet

‚Ä¢ Stock rolling cycle: ~50 days
‚Ä¢ Variation expected: ¬±10%
‚Ä¢ Low credit exposure (2-week cycle in wholesale)
‚Ä¢ Working capital currently funded via internal accruals
‚Ä¢ Expansion funding decision to be taken if required
üè≠ Manufacturing & Scalability

‚Ä¢ No owned manufacturing currently
‚Ä¢ Tie-ups with multiple factories across India
‚Ä¢ Future plan to set up own manufacturing unit
‚Ä¢ No scaling constraints currently
üì¢ Marketing & Brand Strategy

‚Ä¢ Marketing spend: 0.75‚Äì1% of revenue
‚Ä¢ Strong initial footfall at flagship showroom
‚Ä¢ Strategy: South India first, then pan-India expansion

Khazanchi is transitioning from a wholesale-heavy gold player to a retail-driven, premiumized jewellery brand.

The retail pivot is the single largest structural earnings trigger.

Margins are still early in the expansion cycle.

SUGAR STOCKS ; India Sugar Output May Fall; Exports Likely to Be Lower Than Expected - REUTERS

‚Ä¢ üåßÔ∏è Production Risk: Excessive rainfall in key sugar-producing states may reduce sugarcane yields, leading to lower sugar output.

‚Ä¢ üìâ Lower Output Estimate: India‚Äôs sugar production for 2025/26 season seen around 28.5‚Äì29 million tonnes, below earlier expectations.

‚Ä¢ üö¢ Export Constraints: Traders expect India may ship only a part of its export quota due to tighter domestic supplies.

‚Ä¢ üåç Global Price Support: Reduced exports from India could support global sugar prices near multi-year lows.

‚Ä¢ üáÆüá≥ Domestic Price Impact: Limited supply may push domestic sugar prices higher.

üü° Impact: Mixed
Positive for sugar producers due to firmer domestic prices, but negative for export volumes and sectors dependent on lower sugar costs (like beverages/FMCG).

USFDA approval supports revenue visibility in the US generics business and strengthens regulatory track record, though financial impact may be moderate due to limited market size.

Fredun Pharmaceuticals Ltd ‚Äì Q3 & 9M FY26 Concall Key Takeaways

Operational Highlights
‚Ä¢ Capacity expansion ongoing at existing plants; ~37 partner manufacturing facilities operational to support scaling across segments.
‚Ä¢ New-age businesses (Pet Care, Nutraceuticals, Gx, Mobility, Dermaceutics, Cosmetics) continue to gain traction, delivering ~20‚Äì25% YoY growth since launch.
‚Ä¢ Mobility vertical scaling distribution ‚Äî 30‚Äì40 retail outlets being added weekly; expansion into 4‚Äì5 additional states underway, targeting ~60% India coverage.

Financial Highlights
- Q3 FY26: Total Income ‚Çπ160.92 Cr (+57% YoY) | EBITDA ‚Çπ26.34 Cr (+99% YoY) | PAT ‚Çπ10.48 Cr (+96% YoY).
- 9M FY26: Total Income ‚Çπ426 Cr (+48% YoY) | EBITDA ‚Çπ65.66 Cr (+74% YoY)  | PAT ‚Çπ26.98Cr (+96% YoY).
- Margins improved YoY, supported by better operating efficiencies and increasing contribution from higher-margin new-age segments.

Future Outlook
‚Ä¢ No immediate fund requirement for next 12‚Äì18 months; future fundraise only if division-specific opportunity arises beyond that period.
‚Ä¢ Vintage business expected to grow 12‚Äì18% annually over next 5‚Äì7 years; new-age business targeted to contribute 51% of revenue by FY29‚Äì30.
‚Ä¢ PAT margin currently indicated around 5‚Äì6% as sustainable base, with scope for improvement over next 5‚Äì7 quarters as high gross margin (50‚Äì70%) new-age products scale.

Additional Business Insights
‚Ä¢ Q4 remains structurally strongest due to distributor targets and year-end schemes; Q1 typically weakest. Seasonality expected to gradually smoothen as OTC and ethical new-age mix rises.
‚Ä¢ Receivables remain dynamic due to bulk pharma sales model; inventory stable QoQ. Despite strong topline growth, receivable levels reduced materially during the year.
‚Ä¢ New categories to follow an asset-light model ‚Äî selective outsourcing (e.g., mobility equipment) rather than full backward integration.

Management Stance: Management remains conservative in guidance but confident on growth trajectory, driven by scaling new-age brands, steady vintage growth, and gradual operating leverage improvement.

Extended Winter Delays Summer Sales Cycle for Consumer Companies

A prolonged winter and leftover inventory from last year have delayed the summer sales cycle by over 45 days, impacting consumer goods and AC manufacturers.

Peak company-to-trade sales have not yet begun even in southern markets, which typically lead the season.

Summer trade loading, which usually starts mid-January, is now expected closer to Holi.

Retailers are cautious, still carrying 4‚Äì6 weeks of unsold inventory from last year‚Äôs cool summer.

Companies such as Blue Star and Dabur India expect demand recovery supported by GST cuts, pent-up demand, and a warmer forecast.

Prices of ACs and appliances may rise due to higher copper and steel costs and rupee depreciation.

For summer-focused firms, the season can contribute 40‚Äì45% of annual sales, making the delayed start significant.

Hindustan Unilever noted that while winter products performed well, summer portfolio growth has been relatively subdued so far.

India AI Impact Summit 2026 ‚Äî Day 1 just wrapped. Here's what actually matters:

1/ The first global AI summit in the Global South kicked off at Bharat Mandapam. 600+ startups, 300+ pavilions, 13 country pavilions. PM Modi inaugurated and toured booths from Sarvam AI, HCLTech, Jio, and dozens of startups.

2/ The big launch: India's sovereign AI models are here.
BharatGen unveiled Param2 ‚Äî 17B parameter, 22 Indian languages, Mixture of Experts architecture. Built by IIT Bombay-led consortium under DST. Not a demo. MahaGPT is already deployed with the Maharashtra government.

3/ Sarvam AI went voice-first ‚Äî launched Sarvam Vision, Bulbul V3, and Sarvam Arya. Their thesis: India's AI future isn't English-first, it's vernacular-first. Hard to argue with that.

4/ Yotta's CEO teased a big GPU expansion announcement with Nvidia coming in the next couple of days. They've already deployed ~10,000 GPUs. India's compute story is scaling fast.

5/ The hot takes were sharp:
‚Äî Vinod Khosla: IT/BPO services will "almost completely disappear" in 5 years
‚Äî HCL's Vineet Nayar: "You must be dreaming if you think AI will generate employment"
‚Äî Info Edge's Sanjeev Bikhchandani: Learn 10-15 AI tools or fall behind

6/ Global players are betting on India:
Anthropic opened its first India office (Bengaluru) ‚Äî India is #2 market for Claude
AMD partnered with TCS on rack-scale AI infra via their "Helios" platform
Qualcomm pitched hybrid on-device + cloud AI deployment

7/ The expo floor was packed with real use-cases ‚Äî precision farming, sign language translation gloves, AI for special needs education, digital safety tools, and Tata's rural women empowerment program.
Not slides. Working products.

8/ India's AI play isn't about building the next GPT-5. It's about deploying AI at population scale, in 22 languages, for problems that global models weren't designed for.

Day 1 made that very clear. Watching Day 2 closely.

Emerald Finance Expands Earned Wage Access Footprint Across India

Emerald Finance Limited is a growing financial services company focused on salary-linked fintech solutions. Its Earned Wage Access (EWA) platform allows employees to withdraw a part of their earned salary before payday through a simple payroll-deduction system, helping them manage short-term cash needs responsibly.

As of 16 February 2026, the company has expanded its employer network across India.

New Employer Partners:
* Clara Vyapar ‚Äì Uttar Pradesh
* Bholaa Jewels ‚Äì Chandigarh
* Logam India ‚Äì Kanpur
* AKMV Consultants ‚Äì Gurugram
* Vikas Ecotech - New Delhi
* Aruna Enterprise - Haryana
* Dharam Chand Dwarka Das - Uttar Pradesh

These partnerships enable employees to access early wages easily while reducing dependence on informal borrowing.

Each new partnership helps Emerald grow its employee base and improves business visibility. The model carries low credit risk due to salary-linked repayments and generates steady fee-based income without heavy capital use.

With continued employer additions, Emerald is positioning its EWA platform as a stable, capital-efficient growth driver that can support long-term earnings growth and shareholder value.

IRDAI-Life Insurers Meet: CEOs Propose Deferred Commissions Amid Cost Cuts

Key Proposals  
Deferred Model  
- CEOs suggest deferring 40-50% front-loaded commissions over 5 years.  
- Applies to all distributors: agents, corporates, brokers, banks.  

Commission Caps  
- Absolute commissions reduced by 10%.  
- Aligns incentives with policy persistency, cuts acquisition costs.

- Seeks 3-yr distributor-wise commission data by Feb 23.  
- Follows scrutiny on high payouts vs mutual funds/pensions.

- Life insurers submitted deferred proposals; group business pending.  
- IRDAI pushes affordability post-GST zero on life/health premiums.  
- Recent fines e.g. Reliance Gen for disguised commissions.  

Market Impact  
- PB Fintech/Insurance stocks watch: Potential margin pressure short-term.  
- Long-term: Cleaner distribution, lower mis-selling, higher penetration.

**üè¢ Nomura on IT Sector ‚Äî ‚ÄúAI Obsolescence Fears Overdone‚Äù**

**AI Risk Overstated**  
- Nomura believes concerns around AI replacing IT vendors or SaaS players are **oversimplified**.  
- It‚Äôs easier said than done to replace **enterprise-level SaaS products or IT vendors** with AI-driven or low-code apps.  

**Adoption Challenges**  
- Tech adoption for **new or unproven AI tools** remains slow due to **compliance, regulatory, business continuity** and **risk concerns**.  
- SaaS firms enjoy **strong moats** ‚Äî deep data infrastructure, compliance systems, and established client support networks.  

**IT Firms Adapting Fast**  
- Indian IT players have a **long track record of evolving** with emerging technologies.  
- Expect **revenue models** to gradually shift from **fixed-price and effort-based** to **outcome-driven** engagements.  

**Margins and Automation**  
- Ability to **defend margins** will depend on **aggressive internal automation** and productivity improvement.  

**Market View**  
- Current **sell-off in IT stocks** looks like a **front-loaded correction**, not structural weakness.  

**Top Picks**  
- **Large Cap:** Infosys  
- **Mid Cap:** Coforge  
- **Small Cap:** eClerx  

**Key Takeaway:**  
Nomura sees **AI as a transformation lever, not a threat** ‚Äî favoring adaptable IT firms with automation-led margins and outcome-based models.
